title: How to design a successful case study - Quora

response.answer_text: A2A from Halima Ali. Question: How do I design a successful case study? Halima, there are a plethora of examples of case studies for various disciplines available via the web. For example, do a search for “Business Case Study format” and you’ll be overwhelmed with various permutations. Be cautious though; there are a lot of folks / businesses offering their templates for a fee. You don’t have to pay for anything…just due some due diligence. I suggest that you follow the KISS principle (Keep It Simple Stupid). I’m going to assume that you are preparing a case study for a client - there are plenty of other reasons for doing a case study. I always start off with the following basic white paper outline (meant as a decision paper of not more than 2 to 2 1/2 pages): 1) Issue / Problem 2) Background 3) Options 4) Recommendations. I then expand into the following…depending upon the purpose of the case study: 1. Executive Summary - the executive summary summarizes the business case, including your recommendation. This should be stand alone and sufficient to take a decision. 2. Introduction - why / what is the purpose of the study? 3. Statement of the problem - what is the challenge? Doesn’t have to be a problem…can be something such as moving into a new market; change in legal environment; change in competitive landscape, etc. 4. Analysis. 5. Discussion of Possible Options. ... 6. Recommendation. 7. Details of your Chosen Option - this is sort of optional…depending on context of case study. 8. Conclusion. Hope this helps.

There are many ways to do so. A good case study should: Identify a key problemShow what the company did to address the problemIdentify a solution, why it was chosen, and what it proposedState the results of the solution, how it helped, and the ultimate benefitA powerful case study includes a strong heading, graphic, and statistics that speak to the reader, so that they identify with the problem and would be interested in the solution.

In one word: Focus Too much of what I have reviewed, especially at the undergraduate and Master’s level fails because the writers try to cover too much in their topic. When they start the study, they try to cover the entirety of the topic, only to realize that what they are digging into would be too much for even a doctoral dissertation. The end result is a case study that is a mile wide and an inch deep. Or metrically, a kilometer wide and a millimeter deep. One must focus on one element, and delve deeply and completely. Be certain that there are no “what ifs” that have not been addressed.
